description: From Old English misfaran, corresponding to mis- +‎ fare.

entries.meaning: (now rare, archaic) Misfortune, ill fate. [from 14th c.]

verbs.description: misfare (third-person singular simple present misfares, present participle misfaring, simple past and past participle misfared)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To go astray; to transgress, to sin. [9th–16th c.]
(now Scotland) To fare badly; to be unlucky. [from 10th c.]
